The drinks there are delicous! We tried the cucumber/jalapeno which was my fav of the night, but we also had the vodka/elderflower/basil drink which was good too and the bartender special which was a fancy salty dog basically.  The food was ok.  

-The burger was really good actually but I didn't enjoy the pork belly on top as much as I had anticipated. Pork belly is always, at its worst- the shit! But it didn't add to the burger and it wasn't very crispy so yeah it was a texture issue.  

-salade lyonnaise was my favorite of the night the sweet acid from the grapefruit was delicious with the pork biscotti which was like a giant soft crouton- definitely made that salad. Just wish there had been another poached egg to balance the dish better since there was so much acid/grapefruit and as for the candied pomelo-waste of money/time, totally unnecessary 

-Shrimp bisque was very flavorful but kind of atypical, could have used more cream

-the tea smoked tombo tuna simply needed more salt and some acid bad!

-the sizzling tri tip not much to complain about or rave about- it was basically raw good quality meat that we seared ourselves on a hot lava stone-flashy yes. I was craving that mushroom brandy sauce thought but im pretty sure all we had was a side of soy sauce...maybe a change I didn't pay attention to on the menu 

-the liver pate was good for liver i suppose-honestly don't have enough experience with it to be comfortable being a bitch about it since the garlic in it was overpowering, but maybe that's how it's supposed to be cuz liver is kinda gross?

-was excited about the pink peppercorn panna cotta but the fruit leather was just a really gross texture and flavor, the whole dish lacked sweetness, inspiring though- will definitely make my own since the idea is redeemable/inspirational.  

When it comes down to it stick to the drinks- the presentation makes the food look like it's worth the price tag but it sure as hell doesn't taste like it.  Overall an inspirational menu but everything was either poorly executed and/or unbalanced and left wanting- something that could be easily adjusted to super awesomeness.
author: Monica H.

description:
Total diamond in the rough.  A homeless woman shows us where the door was as we were not sure and when we walk in it's like were walked into a Vegas club/restaurant.  Very cool and the food was amazing.  If I could have licked my plate I would have.  Will definitely be going back.

The Pink Lady Ginger Crumble with Bleu Cheese ice cream - best dessert I've ever had methinks.
author: Angela C.

description:
YES, they serve brunch here!

My friend and I were in the mood for some of those delightful crawfish binets from Brenda's Soulfood Kitchen and on our way there passed The Pheonix Hotel's Chambers Eat + Drink. Outside was a chalkboard sandwich board announcing their brunch special, we stopped, thought about it, but continued on to Brenda's for those irresistible binets and made a note to come back to Chambers to try their brunch. Long story short, Brenda's was overcrowded as per usual, so we skipped back down to Chambers. 

This was my first time here, however my friend always raved about their dinner and bar, so I was eager to finally find out what all the hype was about for a place with such a dark exterior, an ominous big red door and possibly one of the grimiest locations in San Francisco. Upon entry the hip, lilac haired hostess greeted us at the door and immediately lead us to a huge red booth which I made myself quite comfortable in. The atmosphere was dim and artsy, with huge retro screen prints decorating the walls, shelves upon shelves of old records and a lit sign behind the bar that shines the words "BE AMAZING", and I instantly thought to myself 'new favorite place.'

So, the service was slow but that didn't change the fact that the food was to die for. I ordered two side dishes, eggs over-easy which are hard to mess up and a plate of biscuits and gravy. The biscuits were so soft and delicious topped with a gravy like I've never tasted, adorned with tiny flowers and herbs, the presentation made it that much more intriguing. To wash down my food, I also ordered their raspberry mimosa which was blood-red and had real raspberries in it. This place, (aside from their slow service) was perfection. Next time I will have to experience a meal poolside however I highly recommend dining inside once in a while. LOVED IT!
author: Alina E.

description:
I went here to celebrate a friend's birthday on a weeknight. It was very quite and only two other tables were taken. But what a beautiful place! It combines a modern look of a high end lounge with the coziness of a coffee house that we all like to have in our neighborhood. I like the old school, Le Colonial like chairs, and shelves of vinyl records. As many places there are in SF to go eat, drink and dance, few have the intimate and romantic vibe. This is clearly one of them. 

The menu is surprising too. Lots of dishes are unique and different. I especially liked the blue cheese ice cream and tri tip kobe that comes on a hot stone. The service has been friendly and unpretentious.  

The place is not cheap but so it shouldn't be, and considering some of the other places in town that are much more expensive and don't have much to back it up with, I am happy to pay the tab at this place.  

I haven't gone to Chambers yet on a weekend night, but I will soon. I hope it's not polluted with the typical weekend crowd.
author: Arkady I.

description:
The Bambuddha Lounge has reincarnated into Chambers, clearly with a positive karmic balance.  The newly redesigned space is now completely worthy of the Phoenix Hotel's nickname as the Rock and Roll Hotel.  The decor drops a hit of sex on you as you walk in, and the food and drink rock you like a 2 hr set of Led Zeppelin.

The space is now lined with lush red curtains with prints of attractive people in enticing positions.  The walls are now all shelves of actual vinyl LPs, and even an old movie film projector.  And the vintage couch-like seating gives it all a comfortable living room/ loungy feel to it.  I got the feeling that Jim Morrison would approve of the new decor.

I came here soon after my friend told me that their burger was awesome.  He knows I'm a quest for the ultimate burger, so I had to try it.  Burger topped with PORK BELLY.  The reality lived up to the hype.

This is one of my top 5 burgers in the city, despite its relatively small size and the bun being slightly cold when I got it.  THAT'S HOW GOOD IT WAS.
once I slapped the bun top on, it became an impressive 6 inch tower of burger, but only about 3 inches in diameter.

I picked up the burger, took a breath, found my center, unhinged my jaw, and took a bite.  First thing was the bun--soft, but slightly cold (read:  a little bit stale tasting).  Then the smoked pork belly hit my tongue where the fat melted in a sinful caress with the smoky caramellized meat/fat crunch placating my inner caveman.  And then the burger itself--well seasoned, perfectly prepared medium-rare.  The lettuce and tomato were clean, cold, and crisp.  I was already on cloud nine with my beautiful companion, but this burger sent me straight to the moon.

The burger came with shoestring fries seasoned with fresh thyme (I love thyme) amongst other things, but thyme being one of my favorite herbs, I thoroughly enjoyed these fries.

While Nopa's burger is simple perfection, this burger... god damn, the smoked pork belly rocked my world harder than any piece of fried bacon could. 

OK, had to get that out of the way.  The rest of the meal, dish by dish:
-Red Bell Pepper Soup.  Smoky, creamy, with chicken mousse on the bottom, and a runny poached egg on top, this soup was a perfect start to the meal, and really gets you ready for the burger with the smokiness.  This soup was genius.

-Tomato "tartare", burrata, tempura fried shiso and green onions, this was also an inspired dish, although it needed some more toast points to go with it.  I really enjoyed how the cold, juicy tomato chunks  complemented the creamy goopy burrata, and contrasted with the crunchy warm shiso and green onions.  And of course the toast points went well but needed more surface area.

-New York Strip.  There were so many ingredients to this dish there's no way I'll remember them all.  They cut the steak up for you (they ended up undercooking this steak to a full rare), served it on thinly sliced caramellized potatoes, and with this massive mix of vegetables on the side.  Luckily both of us prefer rare to medium, so this was fine.

We went on a tuesday night, but the place was rather busy, and our entrees didn't come until about an hour after the appetizers.  Between that, the undercooked steak, and the slightly cold bun, I think they're still working the kinks out of the service.  But that still won't stop me from coming back and having that amazing burger.
author: Fong L.

description: Nice place, good drinks. I am also a fan of the burgers there : delicious !!
author: Marion P.

description:
BE MEDIOCRE

We only had the drinks here, but despite having a somewhat interesting cocktail menu, all the drinks are free poured and all the martinis are shaken. Clearly this place only has bartenders that are capable of mediocre drinks and are not interested in taking things to the next level. This place is about 10 years behind the times in terms of the cocktail scene, and frankly, a disappointment.
author: Brett G.

description: Weird night here. At first there was a huge party taking up all the outdoor space and half the inside, then they suddenly left and the place was almost completely empty on a Friday night. I had one of their specialty cocktails which was fine. I definitely was into the outdoor area with the hip motel theme. Could imagine this place in Palm Springs.
author: Jessie M.

description: The good...the food is delicious and the pool area is bomb. The bad...it's in the Tenderloin. The ugly...lots of homeless people in that area. Anyway, I ordered the Tofu Kale brunch dish and it was amazing! The drinks are also yummy. Our waitress was really great and super sweet.
author: Victoria S.

description:
Update: Air Conditioning is now fully installed and operating.
I was contacted by Isabel to get some feedback on some of the 
service hiccups and truly appreciate the caring, hands on
approach. Looking forward to the Indian Summer patio parties. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
Okay Eat + Okay Drink = Okay.

While Vithiet was ooooing and aahing over the presentation, I was not as impressed. Tri-tip was great, but it takes more skill to actually cook the meat to order as opposed to having your customers lamely "cook" it (unevenly) on a hot stone. The burger seemed underseasoned to me, and the fries were a bit underdone. 

Chambers is a bar that happens to serve food. Not in equal proportions as the Eat + Drink would seem to imply. Service was really good though.
author: Pamela L.

description:
I struggle with writing this review....I'm really leaning towards 2 stars based on the food and service.  However, kudos to turning the old back flip and bambuhda lounge into a fairly classy joint.

Great job on taking this challenging space and making it relevant.  

Now, unfortunately I need to talk about the food and service.  While I respect a well thought out menu , I have more options on Thanksgiving at mom's house then I did on this menu.  Not sure if you were trying to save on paper but good wild....its okay to have more than 4 entree choices and nuts as an appetizer.

As for service it was attentive, but not great.  Nothing else to say, I think its self explanatory.
author: Solbiato S.

description:
I heard about this place from a friend.  I went to check out their website, and it was at that very moment that I made the decision that this was at the top of my list for "must try" places.  I immediately started discussing with a group of friends, and the "Let's Go To Chambers Eat + Drink 2011 Adventure" production was underway.  

So let's recap the day, shall we?

* Woke up, wrestled three alligators, only lost one match
* Skip to later that evening...
* Hopped in a cab to head to Chambers. This place is at the Phoenix Hotel in the Tenderloin, which as most people know, this part of town has a friendly and interesting diverse mix of people...so I do recommend cabbing it or walking with a group of people if you love walking. 
* Showed up around 6:00'ish, everything was pretty desolate outside.
* But what I was told turned out to be true, opened the door and walked into Chambers...a different world completely.
* This place is insanely unique.  Has a bit of a 50's/60's vibe.  It really took me back.  (I was born in the 80's).
* It has a really fun vibe, good energy, etc.
* Had reservations for a smaller group of friends.  We had heard great things about the burger.  So went with the following:

Chamber's Burger $13
prather ranch beef, heirloom tomato, smoked red onion, wagon wheel cheese, whole grain aioli, butter lettuce, challah bun, savory thyme kennebec fries

Had to add the following.  I was going all out:
Crispy braised pork belly $3
Shaved avocado  $2.5

For drinks, went for the specialty cocktails, they seemed like they knew what they were doing:

Drink #4:  Tequila Drink
don julio reposado, american honey liqueur, yellow chartreuse

Drink #6  Cuba Libra
flor de cana rum, sugar cane coke

So the verdict?  They didn't disappoint on anything.  Excellent all around. Oh and I have to mention the atmosphere again.  I just really love it.  They have a huge vinyl record collection that lines many of the walls on bookshelves.  I believe they play music from this collection, have someone DJ etc.  All around solid stuff.  

So I continued the casual conversation with friends, paid out and then transitioned over to the bar area to meet additional friends in our group that were arriving post dinner.  

So the bar area...just go check out the pictures on the website.  There is this "amazing" sign behind the bar.  Name another bar that has this.  I love it.  Again, a 60's or 70's era feel.  Or maybe 2045 depending if we come full circle, I don't know.  It's a killer bar, kinda loungy at the same time with couches and funky seating, DJ playing, cool staff of servers and bartenders.  Oh and then there is the outside by the pool.  I think I'm rambling now, just thinking about wanting to go back.

I'm jumping to the end of my review now.  Go check it out.  It's highly recommended.  When I went here, it was a bit of a hidden find.  I've taken group of friends back multiple times.  I have noticed it has continually become a bit more crowded.  I hope it keeps that hidden find charm though.  That's what really made me love this place.  

I will say they should remodel some of the outside courtyard area.  It's got a lot of potential, but the layout needs some work.  More fire pits and lions.  When that happens, I'm sure I can up this to five stars.  That's it for my portion of the review where I act like I know how to run the place.

Good times.  Go enjoy.  Love Chambers!
author: John R.

description:
Came here with my date and was pleasantly surprised.

At one time I had been here and couldn't quite remember until now, but I believe this was once the Bamboo Lounge.  I think...

Anyway, our Latvian mixologist knew how to serve up some pretty interesting cocktails.  All quite good I felt.

Unfortunately, we could not experience the back area as there was a private party.  So rain check for a revisit to see that part.

The front part is much more casual and so are the patrons.  Good vibe though and good space.  We scored on the couch / lounge area and that was perfect for us this night.  Allowed us to enjoy our drinks, some aps, and get a little close...

Food wise, we had to try the sizzling kobe tri-tip, shrimp bisque, and the truffle ricotta.  All were quite good and balanced.  The kobe was probably our favorite out of the three.

Service was prompt as well and always nice.

Decor is not a Hard Rock Cafe theme.  Much more subtle and record store like in nature, but nicely done.

Overall, I'd recommend a visit to check this place out.
author: Patrick K.

description: We had a reservation, and the 4th and final member of our party was 15 minutes away. We wanted to order a round of drinks and check out the menu, but the hostess refused to seat us. Wow!
author: Tyler K.

description: For being the Tenderloin, the area isn't too bad. The ambiance is great and there's always a place to sit.  The BE AMAZING sign is pretty funny that they have by the bar.
author: Mark A.

description:
Good place in spotty ngbrhood ! Well can't blame the place for that though. 

Drinks are good, bartender are pretty good too! Food depends on chefs mood.. Been there few times.. Hit or a miss!
author: Avi S.

description:
Last week, ya boy went out here to catch a couple bday celebration drinks for fellow yelper, Christine S. 

I walked up around 10:30, and the bouncer wouldn't let us in because they were "up to capacity." But every time, he opened the door and I got a tiny peak inside, the place looked less than crowded to me. WHATEVER. And whenever people walked out, you'd think he'd let some in. Not the case. It was quite confusing. But I don't waste my time getting worked up over bouncers. Not worth it. 

I got in anyway (in your face!) through the back entrance when my friends inside just fished us in through the back entrance. I was totally feeling the décor. Very 60's mod as you can read and tell from pictures. Coming in, I didn't know if I was walking into a restaurant, bar or a lounge. I guess they try to have best of all worlds and combine all genres. The party I was with was there for dinner and I got to sample their leftovers (though I didn't even know everyone there), and I can say the cold fries left on the plate were still good. The Be-Amazing bar was full of 30-somethings but it was surprisingly easy to get a bar tender's attention and drink. Thumbs up!

I don't know if I'd come back for a 10pm drink session, but I am intrigued to have a sensible dinner at a reasonable time. Oh and also, yes there is an outdoor pool patio. Kind of gimmicky, different, but not as cool as I thought it would be.
author: Jon C.

description:
Food is legit.

Apps - Truffle dip with waffle chips was my favorite, ceviche was good, smoking Albacore (yummy) and had a great display as it was still smoking at the table.

Sides - Polenta was so-so

Dinner - Pork was delicious and the BURGER was amazing, kinda smokey and perfectly cooked.

Definitely would go back.

Oh, and of course the wine and cocktails get two thumbs up!
author: Jordana C.

description:
My favorite place to hang out in SF.  This venue seamlessly ties in a lounge, restaurant, bar and even connecting hotel all in one.  Chambers is a good place for both the locals and those visiting SF.

The decor is awesome with its updated 1950s/60s feel with the walls adorned with old records. The crowd is laid back and mature, and the music is super chill and seldom, if ever, play top 40s hits but the DJ manages to keep a steady heartbeat with the crowd.

Last, the burger here is AMAZING.  Hands down the best burger in SF.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
-nice location
-rude and arrogant bar boys
-1 hour wait for drinks
-decent crowd
-people smoking in pool area
author: Nick S.

description:
Not the best place for dinner but would recommend for drinks and appetizers. The cocktail list was impressive and the beer list was decent. Trendy interior but noisy. Loved all of the fun details that went into the unique interior design, especially the records on display.

The neighborhood isn't ideal.. but get over it people!
author: Seema M.

description:
this might be my favourite place in san francisco so far!!!

aside from its shitty location in the tenderloin... this place is bomb.

i came here during happy hour on a wednesday with a couple of acquaintances and it was pretty crowded!  we asked for seating outside because it was a beauuutiful san francisco evening.  this place is connected to the phoenix hotel, so there was a pool, cabanas, and easy access to the hotel in this open courtyardish area.

everything about the inside of the restaurant was incredible!  it's very loungey, and decently sized!  i don't like it when places are too small and get too crowded, but there's a front bar area + middle area with more tables + back area / bar which has a bigger open floor + outside!

the food was great!!  on the pricey side, but you'll probably never try this kind of food anywhere else.  i got some grits fries, my friend got some...fancy figs, and another friend got some kobe beef thing.  their food is rather aesthetically pleasing.

i think it was someone's birthday, which is why it was so crowded, and the service was ....questionably horrible that night.  i say questionably because ... it was the waitress' first night working, and she got our drinks wrong several times, but she made up for it by giving us 3 free drinks :) !!

i'm definitely coming back here again!!  and i have yet to say this regarding anywhere i've been in sf so far :)  i love lounges.  since it's outside + inside, there's room to walk, talk, dance a lil, whateverrrr.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Deserves a solid 3.5.

The service did not go so well the first time around.  But I loved the ambiance and food that I decided to go there again, and for a bachelorette party.

Everything with off without so much as a snag.  We all loved our food, burgers, fried/smoked grits, pork belly sandos, steak, marbles potatoes...and we enjoyed our drink and the service.

The style is def. rocker chic, in my op.  Hundreds of albums adorn their walls, and I can only imagine that lots must go "missing" every night.  The first time I came, I walked in and immediately noticed the Sinatra album displayed.  AH-MAZING.  Should have known then that any place that prominently displays MY man on their walls is A-OK in my book!

P.S.  Def. a fun spot for dinner and drinks.  But equally as fun for drinks alone!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I celebrated my birthday here a few weeks ago and the manager, Isabel, as well as the rest of the staff were very accommodating and helpful with setting up this event for our group.  My party had a wonderful time!

I had been here on one previous occasion during the summer when it was still not as well known yet.  One thing I love about this place is how reasonable everything costs despite how nice the venue is.  I suppose this is due to the location of the bar in the tenderloin... but that's the charm of the spot.  It's definitely a hidden gem.  Having an outdoor area is rare in SF and for a warm October night, hanging by the pool was perfect.  The drinks are all very reasonably priced and well made.  They also have a pretty well stocked scotch selection!  The food is tasty - I think I ordered 5 rounds of bar snacks and it came out to be a LOT less than I thought it would be.

I called Chambers the week of my event and told them I anticipated about 15-20 people.  They immediately reserved a large section of the couches at the bar area for our group even though there was a wedding after party showing up the same night with 100 guests.  The management was great and constantly replenished our table with snacks.  A lot more people came than I had anticipated and they were completely accommodating and allowed my guests to skip the line.  The entire night, I rarely had to worry about whether my guests were having a good time because I knew they were well taken care of.

I had such a great birthday.  Thank you, Chambers!
author: Joanne L.

description:
Love the ambiance. Staff was very friendly and fast...Gotta write this review before my memory's gone (half the night was fuzzy)

1.LOVE the Kobe Tri tip. It comes out on a hot stone and it is just to die for.
2.The burger was AMAZING. The patty just melted in your mouth and it was juicy and super tender.
3.The pisco punch was STRONG&DELICIOUS. For a girly, fruity drink, it sure did pack a lot of heat in that cup.
author: Daisy M.

description:
Super duper.  We had a really fun dinner with a smoking mini-habachi appetizer, another decent app and then a really delicious ravioli entree.  We capped it off with a killer chocolate cake topped with curry ice-cream...
The decor is so cool it could carry the restaurant, but it doesn't need to because the food, service and general vibe is all pitch-perfect.
author: Tammy N.

description:
Diamond in the rough as they say.  
This place is camouflaged in the TL with all the crazies and crackheads that loiter in the area.  Inconspicuous with only one sign at the corner and the doors unmarked. But once you step inside, its Goodbye TL, hello chic new restaurant/lounge.  Definitely one of the more spacious and trendier restaurants in the city.  

Must try: Chambers Burger with Pork Belly add-on.
Ok: Truffle Dip (Mostly butter mix, not enough truffle  and Kobe Tri-Tip).
author: Bert N.

description: I didn't know about the Phoenix Hotel or Chambers Eat + Drink before I came here for an End of Summer Pool Party event. I really liked the interior -- swanky with plush couch seating and dim lighting. We had a bartender outside making drinks. Lawn chairs and tables outside, beautiful weather, warm pool, what more can you ask for?
author: Katherine S.

description:
I keep going back and the quality of food, presentation (I'm always going "Oh! Ah! Wow! when they bring the plates), service and atmosphere remains excellent. Wine selection is also great.
So there, well-earned 5th star!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
We asked the front desk about the attached restaurant and he declared that it served "Comfort food", just what comfort food was to a guy names Miller, and we couldn't wait to find out.  Chamber's was an opportune comfort.

Chambers struck us as tres chic with the walls lined with thousands of vinyl records and a sound track to match. Our starter dish was a truffle dip with wild mushrooms and severed with Ruffles. The truffles dominated the jelly jar it was served in and we wondered again about Millers comfort.  

Next course was chicken liver pate topped with buttered leeks, that where spicy and savory with a raw quail egg. Spread on a crostini this was cherubic. The pancetta roasted figs with a ricotta salata and a balsamic reduction it all floated in as if it was capturing my soul, made me groan with pleasure. These dishes were only $7.00 each and overflowing with smack. The main course of Kobe tri tip steak served on a broiling hot stone that continued to cook the meat if you liked, sizzled our slab.  It came with pickled vegetables and a mushroom brand reduction with a pungent piquancy. I also had the lightly breaded and fried green beans (cause if there are Haricot verts in the house, I order them) adorned with cherry tomatoes, dried olives, gremotlata, and capers. They did the bean justice. 

Executive Chef Trevor Ogden is serving some impressive comfort food that will bring me back every time this hipster in the city. 

We took our wine (a 2007 Foxen Pinot from Julia's Vienyard) and stuck our feet in the pool, amazed and enthralled with the 69's floating below us.
author: Teri B.

description:
My girlfriend was right, this place is life changing!

Came here last Saturday and the place was comfortably crowded.  
Good music with a dance floor, booths, and 2 bars.  LOVE.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Tucked away in the Little Saigon / Tenderloin district, Chambers is a neat surprise amidst the stanky streets and shady residents.

When you first walk in, a giant 'BE AMAZING' sign greets you in bright lights. Walk in a little further and you discover a pretty generous space with another bar in the back. Explore a little more and you discover an open area outside with a lit-up pool. The spacious feel of Chambers really conveys a chill ambiance where you don't feel too claustrophobic. The only bummer was that the people closed off the outside area really early, maybe around midnight. It's probably due to the noise level affecting the neighboring residents, but if so, why build a bar around a residential area?

Chambers is a nice place to come chill on a Friday night, grab some drinks with your buddies, and literally  'be amazing.' 

Cheers.
author: Tom P.

description:
Food can be hit or miss depending on what you order but the presentation of the dishes are excellent. Sizzling Kobe Tri-tip is presented not on iron skillet but on a beautiful hot stone. Tri-tip is so yummy that we had three orders for the 6 of us. Smoked albocore sashmi sits on mini charcoal grill. Bread is served with aioli instead of traditional butter or olive oil. Chicken liver pate, foie gras, hamachi ceviche, crispy polenta and corn chowder are...meh. But the tri-tip may be enough for me to keep on coming back.

Hmm... I wonder if the record collection is real.

Btw, keep your valueables close to you when you are walking in the neighborhood.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Good vibe, terrible service. They've no idea how to manage the place, unfortunately. Shame, really.
author: S M.

description:
Foodie Duty Event #2... Came to Chambers for the first time on a Friday... September 2nd to be exact.  You wouldn't think the inside would look the way it does. 

Shelves of the walls are filled with records.  Legit records... a friend of mine even wanted to take one.  Anyways, onward with the review... 

We had a somewhat large group of ppl... about 12-14.  There isn't a regular booth or table that sits this many people.  So they sat us at a high dining table.  We also were accommodated with an extra sofa-like seating area for the individuals who arrived late.  

Service was great!  Waitresses did a great job of checking in frequently and asking if we needed refills.  Even the store's owner came by to say hello to our group.  

I ordered the sizzling Kobe Tri Tip... it was AMAZING.  The meat comes out on a hot stone and cooks right in front of you.  As a side dish, I ordered the Polenta... which was also amazing!  

Good food, great ambience, and a cool bar in the back!  Don't judge the place by the appearance outside... come give it a try!

FOODIE DUTY!!!
FoodieDuty is a chill dinner party ensemble of family, friends, friends of friends, and friends of friends of friends... you get the point. It's open to all, and a great way to commune over tasty food, drink, while meeting new and interesting FoodiePeeps just like YOU!

We'll EAT, DRINK, then REVIEW (Yelp!) ... it's what we do @ FoodieDuty!

*** FOLLOW us on Twitter @FoodieDuty ***
author: Matthew C.

description:
The first thing you see when you walk in the door is a flashing sign that says 'BE AMAZING' and by golly chambers you are amazing!!!!!

Love the vibe, love the atmosphere, love the crowd, love it all. 

Old records on the wall - diner style booths - high end lighting and decor, you feel like they mixed studio 54 with cipriani NY and bourban and branch.

Its so sexy

I will be back again very soon
author: Shadi N.

description: Cool decor but poor service and average food. Arrived on time but Reservation wasn't ready so we were told to wait in the bar. Every table in the bar area had a reserved sign on it (even though they were all empty). Half hour later still no word on the table. The hostess show no concern whatsoever. Not sure why there were two since both weren't doing much of anything. Once we were finally seated it took over an hour to get food. Really wish it was a better experience since I live nearby but I won't be coming back.
author: Gigi L.

description:
Spot on food! I ordered the biscuits and gravy. My southern friends thought the dish was spot on too. The burgers were a hit. The drinks were good too.. One thing regarding the drinks,  the club soda was consistently flat. Everyone at the table agreed. 

Service was slow to decent... the waiter bought our check two times too early... We felt rushed, when we would have really enjoyed staying longer. Ambiance, very cool and prices fair. 

Summary, I will come again and hope the soda is bubbly and the check arrives only when we ask for it.
author: Jenise C.

description: Creative dishes, ridiculously delicious food. The menu looks a bit pricey but everything is presented artfully and there are tons of ingredients carefully selected to go well together. We ordered the soft scramble. Although there were only a few vegetarian options, those options were no less creative and exciting than the options for meat-eaters. Great seating, too. We were surprised to find this classy place in the Tenderloin.
author: Sarah F. H.

description:
Chambers is an interesting successor to the old Bambuddha Lounge space.  I walked into Chambers expecting a bar and unknowingly stepped in on the restaurant side and was disarmed by people quietly sitting at booths with a dimmed light atmosphere.  I continued to walk through the small maze like a mouse following cheese and eventually came upon the the bar/lounge area.  The bar area has plenty of lounge type seating to get cozy with your friends and enjoy good conversation over drinks.  I especially enjoyed the drinks here.  Aside from the cocktails being delicious, I always love it when a bar uses real fruit/elderflower/mint leaves in their drinks.  

It was a Friday night around 11pm and Chambers never really got full which is both good and bad.  I was surprised because this place just opened up about a month ago.  Overall a good experience and I would definitely return.

Another plus is they serve delicious food until 1am.  After you've had some drinks you'll probably be happy about this option.

4 stars because when you walk outside this place you have hold on to your wallet and watch your back...especially at 1:30am.
author: Ash S.

description: This is a hidden gem in San Francisco! They have great food with a beautiful ambiance! My new spot for having a Relaxing evening without having to deal with drunks at other night spots. Service was perfect :) At first, I was skeptical of this place from the outside, with its rustic appearance.. But it definitely is amazing on the inside and Im glad I came across this place!!
author: Lauren B.

description:
Date/Time:  Sunday - 9pm
Occasion:   Birthday dinner
Party of:  Twenty-three
Ordered:  prixe fixe menu: fish & chips, seared loin, and dessert platter
Total incl gratuity: ~$65pp

The old Bambuddha Lounge updated and redone to a trendy, open space.  Our party was large so we were seated in the back "Be Amazing" bar.   Because we were dining as a group for a birthday, we had a prixe fixed menu set for us.  Our choices on the menu were:
Appetizers: sizzling kobe tri tip or fish & chips
Main entree: chambers burger or slow roasted new york strip loin
Dessert platter

Bear and I got opposites of everything so we could share a nice variety.  The fish and chips and sizzling kobe tri tip are worth mentioning.  The taro chips included in the fish and chips were very crisp and tasty.  Trip tip was red and served on a sizzling stone so one could prepare to your liking.  The strip loin was not as memorable.  The bear got the burger and added pork belly to his order.  I'm not a huge burger fan but this was worthwhile. 

Since we had a prix fixe menu, our cost was fairly higher than if we had just gone for a normal dinner.  At $130 for two, I didn't feel like we got a great value for the food we ate.  Although I wouldn't completely write them off.  I still enjoyed my food and wouldn't mind returning in the future with a smaller group.
author: Jess C.

description: Besides the dicey neighborhood Chambers is this awesome hidden gem. The records that line the wall, the super dim lighting, and light up signage = epic date night. The swimming pool is so amazing. Drink menu is cray cray, you must try the cooper bones, it's a pain to make I can tell by just watching the bartender so be sure to tip him! Can't wait to go back with a nice size group of folks, oh yeah great for large groups.
author: Angelica M.

description:
Expectation and Delivery. 

Any good business understands this relationship and Chambers delivers from what you might have expected from its facade and neighborhood. Bums, crack heads, and urinated cement on the outside - Hipsters, cocktails, and retro chic design on the inside. The food is American tapas-ish. I wish the serving sizes were larger. The cocktails taste great and i think its pretty creative they are on the menu by number and liquor. Love the heated pool area outside at night with the fireplace on and drink in my hand. I need to jump in that pool one day.
author: Charlie L.

description:
This place is a comfy, gorgeous place. The interiors are incredible. The drinks are awesome and the vibe is sexy, chill and soft. I want to hang out here, maybe even move in. 
The staff we met were really nice and welcoming with no attitude.

We had a rather strange request for a special event and they were extremely gracious to us and really went out of their way to help us and make us feel welcome.

The seating is plush and comfortable which is something that's missing in a lot of bars which tend to have hard seats and be cold.

Haven't tried the food yet but the Bramble and the other drinks I tried were great.

Love.
author: Little B.

description:
Wow I had no idea that Bambooda lounge was gone. Granted I had no idea when it changed from Backflip. So the place is totally remodeled and  its a true remodel. Not just a different color paint and some different chairs. The space is completely different. The decor is very cool, you walk in and the walls are filled with shelves of vinyl covers almost like a library.
They have two bars both fully stocked. I judge a bar by the bourbon's they carry and they had decent selection beyond just Makers Mark. 

The vibe is much different than the old club days. Much loungier but very very nice. Also the food was on point. We ordered a couple burgers that were delicious but the item that stuck out the most were homemade crinkle cut potato chips and a cream truffle dip. Nice portion of chips and dip but the burgers are on the slightly smaller side but not overly so. For the quality and taste its awesome but probably need to state that for those thinking they'll get the burger cuz they want a large portion meal. It's not that kind of place.

I went with a couple friends to catch but will definitely be taking the girlfriend here on a date night or maybe to start the night on a night out.
author: Hyung L.

description:
Considering that the TL is a bit dodgey, I thought I would give this place a shot. It has awesome LA/New York-ish decor. Its the first thing I fell for...

Quite to my surprise..excellent food..the sizzling Kobe Tri Tip a must!! I've had steak in Tokyo & Argentina and I have to admit this comes pretty close.

The drinks were #9s all night!! And the manager...very attentive, he took most of our orders. 

Will definitely be back but on a weekday to avoid the B&T crowds...
author: Kristi G.

description: The food was a 5, but the service was a 2. The dishes were flavorful, the presentation was great and the atmosphere is unlike any restaurant I've been to. You feel like you're in the 80s. The downside was that our server lacked the basics when it comes to service: he never brought us water, we ordered bottle service for brunch and he never thought to pour our champagne and orange juice, he brought the check out without asking if we are done yet, etc.
author: Anisha A.

description:
Hands down the new awesome place to be in SF. Even before they were open to the public, we had a really great feeling about this place (possibly because the owners are seasoned in the nightlife arena). Cocktails to die for (the vodka-elderflower is amazing), outstanding food (my boys took down two enormous burgers with pork belly faster than you can say "oh my god there's pork belly on my burger!"), and I can't get enough of the decor. Plus, I got to cook my Kobe tri-tip on a burning hot rock. It may have been my first successful attempt at D.I.Y. ever. 5 stars.

The pool area is beautiful, the indoor wall partitions are made of records - yes- vinyl in sleeves records (People! Stop stealing them!), and the vibe is warm, lively, and sexy all at once. Great wine and cocktail list, gracious and fun service, and oh yeah! Did I mention I got to cook my own steak on a burning hot rock? We'll be spending a lot of our time here and not just for personal reasons...Nice job, guys!
author: Autumn K.

description: Wow. Phoenix located across the street from my hotel and I went there because it was raining. Chambers was like an oasis. An island of calm in a neighborhood of chaos. Chicken breast was best I have ever had. Squash was awesome and they had had Dogfish by the bottle. Over 10,000 LPs!!!! Chambers was a very pleasant surprise and is now a destination spot when I stay in other areas throughout this great city.
author: Peter T.

description: I was very impressed. We came in, it seems small but then you find the place just keeps going and going. Turns out it is huge! The loss of a star is due to the bartender. I ordered a Moscow mule she gave me a really gross lemon drink and there was no getting the attention of any of the bartenders to exchange my drink. Another reason is when we went outside, there was a little fire going and all of a sudden it went out and no one started it again so it was just way too cold and we all had to go back inside. The music was great and so was the atmosphere.
author: Miriam G.

description:
This review is about the LOUNGE/BAR:

One of my many pet peeves: when a bar/lounge makes you wait outside for 20 minutes in the cold only to find out after that there are only 15 people inside. 

I get it, you want to form a line so people can think your place is cracking.  Such an utter disappointment. It's like dating someone and holding out for months thinking it's worth the wait only to find out he's a one minute man that cries after making love. 

Not cool making us wait in the freezing cold in the middle of the Tenderloin.

If Dwell magazine and instagram had a love child, it would be Chambers. Aesthetically pleasing but it's oozing with pretentious hipsters (atleast the night I went)...a little too American Apparel for my taste.  I absolutely love the decor and lighting: from the record shelves to the outdoor cabana.  The place was beautiful.  The drinks are so-so nothing super special.  

PS---street parking unless you plan on spending the night in the motel.  I recommend carpooling with your friends if you are planning on partying here late at night.  It's really not fun walking around here alone.  

+2.5 for now (again, this review is for the bar/lounge not the restaurant).  I will review this place again once I eat here for dinner.  I heard amazing things about the food.  Also, heard this place is fun for bday dinners.  But yes, I'll be updating my review once I return.  It's worth a shot going back to the hood.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: Great food, amazing atmosphere, friendly service and an all around hidden little gem.
author: Robert R.

description:
Perhaps you've experienced a dilemma similar to the one I found myself in on Saturday: the clock had struck 10:30...I was itching to do "something," but hadn't made it out of the house yet...I wasn't quite committed to the idea of going on a bender, per se, but I wanted to do something fun. What to do and where to go?

After hitting this place up on Saturday night, I'm here to report that the answer is Chambers Eat + Drink, located in the Phoenix Hotel on Eddy Street. You'll walk past the hotel parking lot to a couple of nondescript black doors. There's no signage and no doorman. Only a discrete key on the wall will let you know you're in the right place.

But once through the doors, you're immediately greeted to a treat that's distinct and unlike any other place in San Francisco. A friendly host greets you. No pretentiousness whatsoever. Always a nice treat. A bar waits for you immediately past the entrance. Bookshelves filled with thousands of records line the walls and couches are strategically placed to allow one a view of the place, along with privacy at the same time.

The stylistic influence of other trendsetting locales like The Standard in LA and especially the Ace Hotel in Palm Springs is immediately apparent by the retro furniture and lighting fixtures. 

Veering off to the right past the bar will lead you down a short hallway to a lounge/dance area and another bar. A DJ spins a nice selection of mellow hip hop and R&B classics. The crowd is mid-20's to mid-30's; the guys wear distinctive hipster-casual attire, while the ladies are a bit more mainstream. A Chanel here, a Balenciaga there, if you know what I mean.

During warmer evenings, stroll outside to the pool area which has speakers, a separate bar and cabanas set up (although the cabana furniture apparently hasn't arrived yet, since this place is only about two weeks' old). I can imagine that summer daytime pool parties can't be far behind.

Find yourself craving some late night snacks? No problem, the menu features plenty of comfort food, all reasonably priced. 

My brother and I arrived at around 11:15 and easily stayed to shut the place down. Bright light signage behind the rear bar reminds patrons to "be amazing." This place is. Five stars all around. The nightlife game in SF just went up a notch.
author: Sebastian L.

description:
You know the drill with new SF places.  It's usually impossible to get a reservation, period, let alone change the times or amount of people.  You just get what you get.

I had 10pm reservations here on Friday for 2ppl when all of a sudden a bunch of people wanted to come with us.  Of course.  All we had to do was make a call and they were very accommodating, especially with a completely packed house.

Everything we ordered was great.  My favorite was "Tequila drink".

The decor was beautiful, cool, relaxed.  I love the records on the wall.  SF doesn't have ANYTHING like this place and I will be back, a lot.

Thanks for creating such a divine space with great food and drink!
author: Gemma S.

description:
Came by with the Foodie Duty folks for event #2.  Place looked a little weird on the outside, so was a bit skeptical coming in, but you know what they say about judging a book by its cover.  Inside Chambers is a cool spot.

Ambiance and all that was great.  Lighting was just right, well decorated and records all over walls.  Found a legit early issue Rubber Soul vinyl!  Bad ass!!  Little lounge area in the back with big white Sofas and the words "Be Amazing" written in lights... not sure whats up with that but kinda cool I guess.

Food was really good.  This is not Olive Garden folks, if your comin' for a never ending pasta bowl, this is not your spot.  Entrees and Apps are Tapa sized and good for grabbing 3 or so for two people .  Had the Sea Bass, compliments to the chef... it was incredible.  Waitress was great too.  There when you need her, not when you don't...

Cocktail menu was solid too.  Not exactly set the world on fire type artisan stuff, but enough that you feel dumb ordering a Vodka Cran for the third time in a row.  Bar tenders in the lounge area were good and fast.  Accidentally poured us one shot too many and let us keep it no charge... isn't decent customer service a beautiful thing :-)

Give it a try, good date spot... especially if ur a music geek (records on the wall and background music was bomb)

FOODIE DUTY!!!
FoodieDuty is a chill dinner party ensemble of family, friends, friends of friends, and friends of friends of friends... you get the point. It's open to all, and a great way to commune over tasty food, drink, while meeting new and interesting FoodiePeeps just like YOU!

We'll EAT, DRINK, then REVIEW (Yelp!) ... it's what we do @ FoodieDuty!

*** FOLLOW us on Twitter @FoodieDuty ***
author: Andrew J.

description:
Based on the food, I was going to give 5 stars.

After the waiter provided very low levels of service while our group was out at the cabanas, forgot my drink, and didnt provide more than a lame "i'm sorry", I had to drop to 2 stars. 
While I was waiting for my drink from our waiter (who I had to go inside to find after about an hour), I got my own drink from the outside bar (outside bar doesnt have the ingredients to make the drinks on the cocktail menu from inside).

Entree: Had the sole. The risotto that accompanied it was amazing. Slightly sweet; almost reminded me of rice pudding. The Umeboshi added a great sour/crunchy touch.

Grit Fries: yum! little cuboids of crispy grit perfection.
author: Norman P.

description:
Imagine my parents basement...

If they smoked pot...

and my Dad was Steve McQueen...

That is how I feel when I stroll into Chambers.  In a good way!

This is my new favorite spot to grab a cocktail and some tasty fare.

They've nailed it on the decor and the food won't disappoint.

Grab a friend and get to Chambers.

Sexy!
author: Mark C.

description: Chambers is a great brunch place. They have pretty good cocktails. Their pancake souffle is out of this world delicious! Their other dishes are pretty good too.
author: J. L.

description:
Little fancy pants gem in the TL? Nice.
5 stars for food, 3 stars for service.

FOOD:
There were 5 of us. We ALL had the burger. We ALL had it prepared differently. Not ONE complaint. Smoky, meaty HEAVEN. My friend who had it with the pork belly said it was phenomenal, but that she definitely felt like hitting the gym after.

Fries were tiny & crispy, like a fancy version of In'n'Out fries. Delish.

For dessert we split the chocolate ganoche with candied orange & white chocolate curried ice cream. It was tiny-tiny, but we were all too full to finish it. Very rich.

DRINKS:
I didn't have one, but my friends did. The specialty drinks are numbered. Can't remember the first one my friends had (the bramble berry or something) & Drink #4. They really enjoyed them, but they are a bit pricey for how small they are - $11. Hubby had a beer & was impressed by their selection.

SERVICE:
The waitress was very nice, but incredibly inattentive. Bartenders were great, hostess was nice.

SPACE:
HAH! Romantic throwback to the 70's. Wow. Let's just say, if you don't like low lighting, vinyl records, or nudes, you won't like this place. They had the fire place going & it was way too warm for a summer night.
author: Mars F.

description: James the bartender is phenomenal! My girlfriends and I sat at the bar and had such a good time. He was really creative, friendly and made us drinks not on the menu, catering to our wants, sweet, bitter, gin, etc. Each drink we had (and we had many) was creative and so so delicious! I haven't tried the food, but for the bartender and drinks - I give five stars!!
author: Tess G.

description:
We went to Chambers for the first time on a Thursday night at 6 pm. Glad we got there early. There was a perfect sofa and coffee table configuration in front of the fireplace. It' was perfect.    We met a friend and her 8 yr. old son. I had some trepedation about meeting  a friend in a lounge with a kid but they were super accommodating. I am glad that we got there early to get a seat. 

I think if you are going to eat dinner or meet a group for drinks, reserve your spot. 

Drinks were 5 out of 5 - we had a few drinks off the menu. 
Service was 5 out of 5 - our waiter really watched the table, knew all of the items on the menu and my water glass was never empty for more than 5 minutes and I drink a ton of water. He also was not intrusive but there when we needed him. 

Food - we had an order of the Truffle and chips (i loved the chips but not the dip 3 out of 5), Bar nuts (5 out of 5-unique and amazing), Smoking Hamachi was original in presentation with great flavors (5 out of 5), Salmon with forbidden rice porrige (4 out of 5) and Fish and Chips very good. 

The ambiance is great for a date, a dinner out, a drink with friends, and the record collection, dark wood, fireplace and candles really worked for me. 

We plan to come back before and after we hit a show at The Great American. 

This is a great place, I woulid check it out but make a plan because it's a cool place and like most cool places it is in demand. 

Glad we checked it out.
author: Amanda J.

description:
a bit expensive for me for what you're getting. i've heard some people were just so-so about their food, but i enjoyed all the dishes i got. i was just a bit surprised by the bill when i got it based on what we got. anyways, we ordered

- chicken liver pate - delish, loved the quail egg on top, nice addition
- yellowtail ceviche - the banana chips were crispy and delish. yellowtail was good
- sizzling tri tip - it seems like it comes completely raw and  you use the stone to cook the meat. VERY cool concept. however the stone doesnt cook taht well... we sent it back to get another stone b/c there was literally meat blood still dripping.. i like med raw but thats just a bit too much for me 
- smoking pork belly - DELISH. i love pork belly. if you do, get this 
- chocolate terrain - we felt like eating chocolate. and we did. the curried ice cream!! different but yummy! 

as for drinks, i couldnt get enough of the "whiskey drink"!!! i couldnt even order anything else cause it was so good!
author: Jen S.

description:
Totally different from the exterior, it's a whole new world inside. I liked the wooden interior with dimmed lights and a back room that feels more like a lounge. We went to the back bar to wait for our friends and took a look at the drink menu. With so many good flavors, we didn't know how to choose.

Also, if you sit in the chairs with a cover, you hear all the noise getting sucked into the cushion. I lean out of the chair in order to hear my boyfriend.

I got the #2: bramble drink. Tanqueray, lemon, sugar, blackberry and mint. I'm not even a big gin person, but the drink here was delicious. Although, I could really taste the Tanqueray, I was able to drink about half before I started flushing. The blackberry made it flavorful and sweet.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I have been patiently waiting for this spot to open for a few months now. I was starting to get worried that the area that used to be called Bambuddha lounge, was going to remain and empty &* desolate as some of the store fronts on Market street. 

When I finally checked out this spot, I was more than satisfied, I was impressed! The cocktails are reminiscent of a Bourbon & Branch speakeasy style - appeasing to the eye and full of unique spirits. The staff was friendly & attentive, and space itself has been completely remixed. 

I live right next door to this venue and I am extremely happy that spots like these are finally bringing some class to this neighborhood. There's no doubt that I will visit this location again.
author: Michael H.

description:
Holy crap this is a hidden gem. After seeing more than two dozen couples ahead of us at Brenda's, we decided to branch out and try something else. Chambers came up on Yelp, and we looked at the spot on the map, scratching our heads. What restaurant? There was that odd Phoenix Hotel that seemed like it was loaded on a flatbed truck in 1976 Los Angeles and trucked to San Francisco. Maybe it was in there? Well, it is, in fact, through a pair of nondescript black doors that open directly only the Eddy sidewalk.

Inside the 70s motif (intentional? I can't even tell!) continues. There's old LPs on shelves and what looks like old Bond movie artwork. Happily, everything is fresh and clean; this place isn't a downtrodden refugee from the 70s so much as a Doctor Who, just-stepped-out-of-a-portal-from-the-70s place.

Anyway, it was a 30-45 minute wait, but the bar was open and serves the full menu, so we happily sat there. The cocktail menu wasn't super long, but it had some interesting drinks, so my wife went ahead and ordered one, while I got an Arnold Palmer and we put in our order.

I got the soft scrambled eggs and my wife got the eggs royale. The food took a little while to come out, but when it did, it looked good and tasted AMAZING.  The vegetables with mine included sweet snow peas that were lightly cooked and brushed with something so that when combined with the scrambled eggs they achieved a perfect breakfast pairing of sweet and savory. My wife's sous vide eggs sat on a bed of fried potatoes that sort of split the difference between hash and mash, and were crispy without being dried out or at all greasy. The sauce that emerged from the eggs and the sauce could not be wasted, so we also ordered some dry toast with which to sop up the remains, which turned out to be a bit of a revelation on its own. They very obviously make their own bread, and it's fantastic. It absolutely did not need anything to be delicious, though of course it was also good with hollandaise and egg yolk.

Add to this that Dylan, the bartender who served us, was both really friendly and made drinks that were just as shockingly good as the food. It's not often that my wife will spend a good five minutes trying to figure out all the tastes in a cocktail, becoming somewhat embarrassed at how pretentious she sounded when she tried to explain them to her teetotaling husband. Except that she didn't sound pretentious at all, and anyway it turned out that the very same Dylan had spent a long time adjusting the mixes to achieve those exact tastes. He's a young fellow, but he must be really dedicated to his art. My Arnold Palmer was also good; clearly made of actual lemonade and tea; refreshing and only a little sweet.

Extra points for having a uniformly friendly staff, including the bartender who wore a Star Wars shirt that especially cheered us.

Really, I was completely blown away. It wasn't a cheap meal and if you were looking for Brenda's-level portions you'd be disappointed, but having dined recently at some really ritzy places that were more than twice as expensive, there's really nothing those places have on this one. The location is pretty "Tenderloin," but once past those somewhat forbidding black doors, it's plenty classy, yet it doesn't make you feel out of place if you didn't dress up. This place deserves to be at the top of the short list.
author: Nathan P.

description:
NOTE: This review is just for the Lounge.

I stopped by Chambers on Friday for a friends birthday. It's actually a nice venue. They aren't located in the nicest area, but once inside the venue it is quite nice. They have a decent outdoor area with a pool and fireplace. There are two bars inside (one near the restaurant area and another further inside). 

There was also a decent crowd.

So why the 2 stars? A specific bartender, who was shady! Upon arrival my buddy and I decided to get some drinks. On our first round of drinks we ordered from a female bartender. Without thinking twice I paid with a $100 bill, before she actually had a chance to tell me the price. I didn't realize that she'd be shady. When she came back with my change she gave me  $77 back (no receipt, which I saw her throw away). I didn't really think much of it at the time, and I left and extra $4 as tip. However, on our second round we decided to try the guy bartender, because we thought our first drinks were kinda weak. Upon ordering the same drinks he charged us $20. I then realized the first lady short changed me in order to get a better tip. I realize that some people may leave lousy tips, but its totally uncalled for to just short change your customers. I left a very generous tip for two drinks that should have cost $20 (I left $4, and she took another $3).

I really wanted to love this place. The venue is nice and it seems like a chill place to hang out, but it really bothers me that a bartender would try to take advantage of customers.
author: Richard P.

description: Great food but on a smaller size. We tried almost every appetizer. My favorite was tri-tip, the presentation on a hot rock was really interesting. The atmosphere is great. Perfect place for business happy hour.
author: Nadia A.

description:
I love this place.  I feel so welcome here, even after just a few visits.  I love the lamb shank - so tender, and with lots of veggies on and near it for a great complement.  I also have tried the burger - it is better every time I order it.  I know they offer shaved avocado and/or crispy pork belly on top, but I am content with that slab of heirloom tomato that comes with.  I am a big tomato fan - that wins for me.  Another meaty bit is the Kobe beef tri-tip that comes out sizzling on a hot stone.  I love tri-tip, and the mix of julienne veggies that comes with it.  The meals are balanced here - well thought over.

And - of course - Chambers is a bar, too!  The drinks are high-quality and always fresh - just what you would expect from the Manchesters.  They have always been so stylish, but they really nailed this one.  The furniture and decor are worth the trip by themselves.  The feeling gets better when you are sitting in such splendor, sipping a great drink.  The sign encourages you to be amazing.  An easy task here.

Finally, I have to mention the service.  This is where Chambers is going to excel over its lifetime.  These people make every guest feel like a VIP.  They make the hard work look easy and fun - even while they are devoting themselves fully to you and me.  I'll be back!
author: Graham W.

description:
Ordered the tri tip n chambers burger with pork belly like some people here recommended on yelp. Got my food n finished it fast because I was starving. 

When I saw my food come out, especially the tri tip, I was very disappointed. The meat amount was literally shaped like the size of an IPod nano with 5-6 small pieces pre cut. And that cost $16 just for that little crap.

The burger was small too, and I don't know what everyone else had tasted from both the dishes I ordered, but it was both mediocre to me. The burger with pork belly was $17 and I rather spend $5-8 and get a delicious Nations burger instead.

I also had two alcoholic drinks, one old fashioned and one Cuba libre. And each was $11. Tried a few appetizers with my group and overall all the food was really salty. 

Prices for what you get are totally not worth it. I rather take my $50 n spend it at House of prime rib or Harris restaurant where I will be full for sure after. 

And let me add that I came here starving and didnt eat for several hours before and after eating here, my stomach felt bloated n uncomfortable. And a hour later I had diarrhea more than once. It was definitely because of here. Either a dirty unclean fruit from my alcoholic drinks, dirty glass, or something in the food was dirty or maybe either the food prep or bartender didn't wash their hands?

The only good thing was the service and music from this place.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
The whiskey drink I had was one of the most perfectly mixed cocktails I'd had in a long time. It was strong without being weighed down by an alcohol after taste.

The truffle dip is Y U M. Super truffle-y flavor with chips that have just the right amount of crunch.

I didn't have a full meal, but I will be back to give it a shot!
author: Ross A.

description: I came here for a birthday brunch. They were super accomodating to fit a larger group when I called the day before. They have bottomless mimosas for $14 (AMAZING), and the food was very good. I think the burger was the overwhelming favorite for what our table ordered, but all of the food was good. As a side note, Vick (our server) was AWESOME!
author: Jess K.

description: Trendy lounge, cozy ambiance - great for date night. Pretty drinks, but too bad they aren't made strong! Definitely don't come here for a heavy meal. Nibble on a few apps -- try the sizzling tri-tip and pass on the tots!!!
author: Joanna N.

description: Love this place. Every time I am in the area I always seem to end up here. It has changed a bit though over time, as its more of a "club" scene now but its still mellow enough for me to hangout without feeling like I am at an international meat market.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
First off, this place is classy. Yet somehow, it's also more "real" and authentic than a dive bar. 10,000 actual records serve as decorations throughout the joint, making me feel like I'm hanging out in my (future) expensive loft with my (present) music collection. 

And speaking of music, this place nails it. On the two separate occasions I've been there, the DJ was spinning tunes that were at the very least enjoyably non-intrusive, and at the most, conversational centerpieces among my group. I had to ask the DJ about his collection, and was amazed to hear he was spinning the vinyl right off the walls. Decor you can actually hear. Legit.

The food is tasty as well, though the drinks are the showstoppers. I'm not usually one to invest in high-end cocktails, though these are well thought out pieces of art. The prices are standard for higher-end fare, and don't expect them to pricematch with their TL neighbors, but everyone left feeling like they got more than their money's worth. Big ups to my new oasis in "little saigon".
author: Stef V.

description:
Chambers is such a fun restaurant. Its not in the best part of town but worth the trip. I went there with some friends before heading to the movie theater a few blocks away. It was hard to find the entrance.  If you go, look for two wooden doors on the side of the Phoenix Hotel!

We ordered the vegetarian option which is listed in tiny letters at the bottom of the menu.  We told the server what kind of veggies we liked and didn't like and he created a dish for us! If you love veggies, I highly recommend it! Tomatoes and mushrooms sit on top of black lentil beans on top of a cauliflower puree that looks like mashed potatoes. All topped with a lime drizzle.  Yum!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Chambers is right next to The Phoenix Hotel.  It looks totally sketchy from the outside, but it's got a cool, funky vibe once you enter.  There are tons of outside tables, which is great for weekend brunch.  They also play music, so you are seated poolside listening to music, eating bruch.  It's awesome.  

Service and food were good also.  Not much to complain about, other than I wish they had a few more options but it's hard to screw up breakfast, especially when you've got a table outside, lots of space and music.

The lounge looks cool also.  We definitely want to come back for cocktails!!
author: Kim D.

description:
The music in this place is superb.  The food, wine, service, and ambiance are bar none compared to all the other incarnations this place has been.  
Maybe, the new place could restart the WET parties that used to be here when it was the Backflip.
author: D B.

description:
Chambers is a chill spot, great for dinner, drinks and just catching up with friends. The food is and drinks are delicious. The (Be Amazing) bar and outdoor area is great for groups and a few friends. 

Pros: The chill atmousphere, the delicious food and drinks

Cons: Not in the greatest part of SF and pricey $$$
author: Kevin T.

description: Ahh Chambers....how I love thee on a Friday evening. Nice low lighting, great happy hour, pleasant staff and a kickass manager Ashleigh. She checked in with our table, answered all our silly questions and took care of us all night. Overall good feel!
author: Zoe M.

description:
Stopped in for a drink after work on their second night of operations.  Not sure it's exactly the happy hour joint (was mostly empty but the hostess still watched us select our seat with hawk eyes), but it definitely has potential to be a great late night lounge venue.  Decor takes the cake for sure, and outshines both the food and the drinks.  Urban, clean, sexy and yet still somewhat rustic, shabby and inviting.  Loved all the wood paneling, oversized seating, banquets and mood lighting.  The front is set up for dining and some drinking, whereas the back is all drinking and lounging.  Drinks were delish (names escape me) and strong, though we were upset they didn't have any happy hour specials (perhaps that has changed now).

Interesting outdoor patio that is shared with the hotel...wonder if it will get much use (let's be honest, SF isn't exactly known for our balmy summer nights)...but could be nice for daytime drinking.

Would definitely go back late night to check out the scene.  Felt very 'adult' without being stuffy.  Oh, I would like to suggest some additional throw pillows for the back room...all the seats are very deep, making it somewhat awkward/uncomfortable.
author: Morgan B.

description: It's a pretty sick place behind closed doors . Has a pool area and the bar itself looked awesome
author: Aman K.

description:
Went for dinner last night, a friend's 30th birthday party.

This hotel/ restaurant has a Rock N Roll feel, with great patio seating, dim lighting, cool bar inside.  They have a decent wine selection and a wide range of prices which is nice.  The cocktails are really strong! These are the best features of the restaurant. 

The service at this place is poor at best.  We sat at 8, got our appetizers just after 9, and our main course just after 10.  It seemed like a really long  wait to eat.  The appetizer my friend and I split was the Hamachi ceviche.  The dish was small, and not enough for two, it was a let down after waiting over an hour.  We both had the burger for dinner, which neither of us cared for.  After waiting for over two hours to eat we were ready to get out of Chambers.  The service is some of the worst I've seen in San Francisco.  The manager came to assure us two occasions are food was on it's way, but it just never seemed to come out, I felt like they had forgot about our table.  There were 15 people in our party.  They forgot to bring food out to several people in our group.  It was just a bad experience on a great night for my friend.  I wouldn't come back here.
author: Travis B.

description:
Great place! A friend and I wanted to celebrate our bdays somewhere in SF and were looking for a fun/trendy lounge to gather everyone. This ended up being the perfect venue! Really nice decor, great music and a fun 70's vibe to it. Isabel wasgreat; very friendly and helpful and made sure we got a table area for our big party! 

We also brought cupcakes with us and they brought it out for us later in the night on a big plate with candles.

Also, the pool area outside is very cute! Only thing is I wish there were more heat lamps! 

I definietly recommend the lounge and will be going back soon!
author: Kimia K.

description: Went there for brunch. The food is below average but liked the ambiance. I ordered ice coffee and they gave me hot coffee with ice. What? And my main was tofu scramble type vegetarian dish and was unbearably salty. For the price of food, I would expect a lot more.
author: June C.

description: I sorta wish I'd not eaten at this place nor tried any of the specialty drinks because none of it was all that great and $60 later I'm still hungry. The $27 "steak" was 5-6 1/4" slices of beef with a little mashed potato, mushrooms, and a couple of other items for dressing/sides. Overall it looked like a $27 appetizer after having the $14 pork appetizer that was like 3 bites. Don't get the fernet #1 drink as it tastes like pine. Like this place for the vibe but I'll never eat here again. Nothing about that steak was all that fantastic for them to be so skimpy and charge so much money. I'm happy to come to this place for social drinks but from now on I'll go to Turtle Tower for dinner or something where I spend 1/4 the price and have great quality food. Or go to Bobo's where I'll be full after spending $60 on a steak and a side.
author: Michael K.

description: Really amazing food and cocktails. They have a happy hour that we caught the end of which was great. Order many small plates and you will be happy! The steak on the small plates menu was my favorite, I would eat 4 of those for 1 meal!
author: Amber M.

description:
We accidentally stumbled into this hidden gem while wait listed at Brendas. Right off the bat, the decor caught our eye. Definitely an old school 1950 feel to it. As we head more into the restaurant, we realize that there are cabanas outside and a pool. Cabanas in SF?! Cool! Kinda felt like we were in Vegas. 

We had to the bar to grab some Mimosa (which are all made from fresh fruit). The bartender a genuine sales guy. He deterred us  from the mimosas to try other items on the menu. He recommend this type of earl grey drink ($10) and bloody mary ($10). Both were really tasty! 

I'm looking forward to coming here for dinner and drinks sometime in the near future.
author: Andrew C.

description: Loved the decor and they have super inventive brunch food. Plus, you can make reservations, which is awesome when it comes to brunch lines in SF.
author: Turi F.

description: Nice venue for drinks.  Have come here for a couple of birthday parties and it can get a bit warm, but I like the decor and the lounge seating area.  Got a good vibe.  The neighborhood can be a bit sketchy at night  - I've seen a couple of street brawls - so bring a friend.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Overall, this was a great dining experience!

Price - 3 - It was on the high side
Ambiance - 5 - Loved the theme
Service - 5 
Food - 4

This restaurant is in the Tenderloin... I grew up in SF so these things don't bother me but I can see how some may be put off by the neighborhood... Get over it, people won't bother you if you mind your own business.

I had the best service from the Maître d', Michelle, I spoke with her several times during the reservation process.  She greeted us at the door and was very personable.  She did it right... none of that pretentious shit you get from other trendy spots.  I really hate all the yuppy and pretentious hosts around the bay.  Anyway, kudos to Michelle for setting the tone.

Service from our waitress was also very good, personable, and prompt.  Service was spot on here.

Ambiance... where do you start?  I loved the 70's retro style.  It was very cool and it felt like I was living in that era... seemed like a cool era.

Food was overall really good except for a few minor misses.  The beef plate (tri tip or filet) was superb.  We also had the pork dish, spare ribs, potatoes, lamb, and several others.  Overall, nobody complained we just ate!  Beer selection was decent and their mixed drinks were ok.

We all felt the bill was a tad high but given the overall experience, we will likely be back.  4 people, all drinking, tons of food, about $250 with tip.
author: Ed W.

description: This place used to be a great place with nice ambience and delicious food. We had a dinner here tonight and I must say I was pretty disappointed. The food was mediocre at best and service was slow and distant. We were not very hungry so we just ordered the main courses knowing that they would be rather small. I got the swordfish, that was barely warm and came with cold cooked vegetables and cold sushi rice. The taste was almost completely missing. My company got the steak. It was also cold and was served with barbecue sauce and cold vegetables. Only the red wine was served hot. What used to be one of the best hidden gems of the city seem to have turned into a disappointment. Wish we had just had some ethnic food in the neighborhood. That would have been fast, tasty and with probably better service.
author: Tomi M.

description: Wow, thank you Kasey S. for introducing me to such a fun late night place! Sure it's not the in the best part of town and I wouldn't recommend hanging out or walking around at 2am after a fun night of partying, but this was such an unexpected place. I can only review it on late night Saturday fun, but I love the lounge atmosphere and thought the arrangement was interesting. When you first walk in it looks kind of small but as you walk down the hall to the left, it extends to more seating area and another bar area in the back. Great place for gatherings!
author: Kim-Anh P.

description:
The food used to be soooo good too bad they changed the menu and the chef I guess , it isn't the same anymore.. 

The service is great and the interior looks great, I just wish the place was less noisy so we could enjoy the ambient ...
author: Nora A.

description:
This is a place I usually wouldn't like all that much, but I had a good time here.  It's in the tenderloin, so it's not a great area, but you walk inside and it's pretty hip and trendy... it's by a hotel there so it has a old hotel/diner layout? but totally supremely remodelled to be modern and fashionable.  There's a small bar up front w/ some tables, then a long narrow area w/ more tables and in the back there's a slightly bigger bar.  We were there 7:30 PM saturday so it should be packed, and all the tables were, but it's no problem to find a spot at the bar and get a drink... cocktails were pricey.. $11 i think?... anyway, our table was ready, and we sat down and it's tight quarters, but they do everything well.... I liked our server... foreign.. I'm guessing she's ukrainian (i have no idea... she could have been swedish.... she was blond and spoke w/ a thick accent)...but she was unassuming and helpful and not pretentious unlike some servers can be at trendy places like this...anyway... we got the truffle dip which was tasty... they probably make a killing off of that... the tritip thing on the sizzling round hot stone was just OK... the crudo was good, I don't remember what else we got... but the reason why this is 5 stars is the burger.  I ordered it medium rare and didn't get anything extra (they offer avocado and porkbelly on it), but I just got it as is... it's probably one of the best burgers I've had in san francisco.  Very distinctly smokey... I love butter lettuce, single slice of tomato.. I don't remember any pickles, but the smoked red onion? was awesome... but the kicker was the aioli.. it was a whole grain mustard aioli? loved it..... meat was nice and juicy and well seasoned and the whole thing was just the perfect size burger... patty not too fatty.. not too small....  and I like the fact they don't have to put bacon on it to make it tasty.

this place was pretty pricey in the end.. we didn't get dessert, but it was like $80 a person b/c of all the drinks and appetizers/sides... 

bathroom was clean.
author: Easter E.

description:
The is probably my favorite lounge in SF. 

The drinks are kinda pricey, but they are well made. We ordered some appetizers too, and it wasn't very good. 

My review is only based on the drinks and the atmosphere of the place.
author: Abhi M.

description: I really liked this place.  Have been here once for dinner and once to just have drinks with friends.  Highly recommend the tater tots, kobe beef, and pork belly appetizers.  Tried the bramble, vodka drink, and spicy cucumber cocktails (the spicy cucumber was my favorite).  The crowd is diverse and there's a fun outdoor area with heat lamps to keep you toasty.  It is walkable from Civic Center Bart, but watch out because it's smack dab in the middle of the TL.
author: Pam S.

description: This is a hideaway for sure..... stands alone in the lousy area of the Tenderloin (is that an oxymoron ?) I stay in the Tenderloin and noticed what looks like a drive in motel many times....the Phoenix!  You will not believe how cool it is inside...once you find it! There are actually what I call ....2 areas. The front when you walk in is loud and somewhat like a club/bar scene.
